DOCNAME: CASE OF THOMPSON v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 5-3;Violation of Art. 5-5;Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 6-3-c;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . At the relevant time he was a Lance Corporal in the NORP army stationed in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE he was reported to his Commanding Officer on a wounding charge , which incident had allegedly occurred in DATE . On DATE he was arrested on CARDINAL unrelated charges of failing to attend and disobeying a lawful command . On DATE he appeared , on the orders of his Commanding Officer , on the latter CARDINAL charges and he was reduced to the ranks . On DATE he was also remanded for an abstract of evidence ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to be compiled on a charge of wounding with intent to do grievous bodily harm contrary to section CARDINAL of the Offences Against the Person Act CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE he went missing from his unit . On DATE he was arrested in GPE by the civilian police , charged with aggravated burglary and handed over to the military authorities . When it was discovered that he had been absent without leave , he was placed in close arrest in the guardroom of GPE garrison . On DATE he was escorted under close arrest back to GPE .

CARDINAL . The Government maintained that a copy of the information pamphlet entitled “ The rights of a soldier charged with an offence under the Army Act DATE ” ( DATE edition ) would have been available to the applicant at ORG garrison and would have been provided to him against signature of a form acknowledging receipt . Since the relevant disciplinary file was lost , the Government could not provide a copy of the form . The applicant accepted that he received a copy of the pamphlet while in close arrest in GPE and that it was likely to have been the DATE version of the pamphlet .

CARDINAL . On DATE he appeared before his Commanding Officer who remanded him in close arrest and ordered an abstract of evidence to be compiled on the absence without leave charge with a view to that Officer applying for power to award extended detention ( paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . No such application was in fact made . During that hearing the applicant received a copy of the charge sheet ( the absence without leave charge ) .

The applicant maintained , and the Government denied , that at that same meeting he was asked by his Commanding Officer whether he would be pleading guilty or not guilty and that he had indicated the former .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appeared before his Commanding Officer when the latter read the charge of absence without leave and formally asked the applicant whether he pleaded guilty or not guilty . He pleaded guilty and he was awarded CARDINAL days’ military detention . On DATE he was also remanded for trial on the wounding charge .

The applicant claimed that he was not afforded the opportunity of electing trial by court - martial whereas the ORG submitted that he would have been given this option by the Commanding Officer before the finding of guilty was recorded on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appeared before a ORG in GPE ( GPE ) on the aggravated burglary charge and was remanded on bail until DATE . He completed his military sentence of imprisonment on DATE . He was then informed by his Commanding Officer that he was to be retained in close arrest until his trial by court - martial on the wounding charge . He was then released to open arrest on DATE following representations by his civilian solicitor . In DATE the civilian prosecuting authorities discontinued the burglary proceedings . In DATE a notice of temporary discontinuance issued as regards the court - martial proceedings on the wounding charge . No further action on that charge has been taken against the applicant who was subsequently administratively discharged in DATE for reasons not related to the afore - mentioned charges or conviction .

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice contained in LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) , LAW ) DATE and LAW ( “ QR ” ) are outlined in the PERSON v. the United Kingdom judgment ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , PERSON , ORG § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the Army Act DATE which regulated court - martial procedures are set out in the GPE v. the GPE judgment ( DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-I , § § DATE ) .
CARDINAL . Following LAW CARDINAL ( Commencement No . CARDINAL ) Order ( adopted on DATE ) , LAW ( “ the LAW ” ) came into force into force on DATE . LAW reads as follows :
“ Nothing in LAW insofar as it relates to LAW [ the new procedures for dealing with offences under the various Services Acts ] to the LAW shall have effect in relation to –
( a ) any summary dealing or summary trial ,
( b ) any trial by a court - martial or a standing civilian court , or
( c ) the hearing of any appeal by ORG ,
which commenced DATE . ”

CARDINAL . The CARDINAL Act significantly amended court - martial procedures and the new system is also summarised in the PERSON judgment ( at § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) and is outlined in more detail in the case of ORG v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . MONEY , § § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL ) . The references below are to GPE prior to its amendment .
CARDINAL . Absence without leave is an offence under LAW , the punishment for which includes imprisonment for a maximum of DATE .

CARDINAL . An allegation that a person subject to military law had committed an offence had to be reported in the form of a charge to the Commanding Officer , who would investigate . When a Commanding Officer did so , he had to read and , if necessary , explain the charge to the accused . He had to either hear evidence orally himself ( summary of evidence ) or cause it to be reduced to writing ( abstract of evidence ) . The latter was obligatory if it was considered that the matter could be dealt with summarily and extended detention could be awarded on any finding of guilt ( see “ summary punishment ” below ) . Having heard the evidence , the Commanding Officer had to determine whether the accused was guilty or not and had either to dismiss the charge or record a finding of guilty in which case he could award CARDINAL or more of the prescribed punishments .

CARDINAL . If , having heard the case , the Commanding Officer considered the accused to be guilty and that he would award a punishment greater than a reprimand or a minor punishment or a punishment involving a forfeiture of pay , he could not record a finding of guilty until he had afforded the accused the opportunity to elect trial by court - martial ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act ) . An accused could have TIME to so elect . Even if an accused elected trial by court - martial immediately , the Commanding Officer gave the accused an opportunity to withdraw his election DATE and , if he did not so withdraw , the accused would be remanded for trial by court - martial . Thereafter he could only withdraw his election with the consent of the Commanding Officer ( prior to remand for court - martial ) or the court - martial Convening Officer ( after remand for court - martial ) .
CARDINAL . The pamphlet entitled “ The rights of a soldier charged with an offence under the Army Act DATE ” ( DATE edition ) contained the above information ( “ the information pamphlet ” ) .

CARDINAL . If an accused was a soldier , his Commanding Officer ( not below the rank of Field Officer ) could award detention for DATE or , if extended powers were granted , for DATE ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL)(a ) of the CARDINAL LAW CARDINALA of ORG DATE ) .

CARDINAL . NORP QR CARDINAL provided that , following an accused ’s election for trial by court - martial , a charge could not be increased in gravity before the court - martial unless evidence of a more serious offence subsequently became available . As to punishment options available to the court - martial , QR CARDINAL provided as follows :

“ If an accused has elected to be tried by court - martial his punishment is not for that reason to be increased . In ordinary circumstances , the court should not award a heavier punishment than that which could have been awarded summarily . However , the court sentencing him is not bound by the limits imposed on summary awards ... ”
CARDINAL . The information pamphlet contained the above information .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act set down a procedure by which an accused ( a warrant officer , non - commissioned officer and a soldier ) could complain to ORG if he considered himself to have been wronged in any manner by his Commanding Officer . LAW made similar provision for complaints by officers .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provided that ORG and certain senior officers “ may ” review a finding or award emerging from a summary trial . On any such review , the reviewing body or officer could quash the finding if it considered it expedient to do so and/or could vary the award by substituting a less severe punishment .
